items.title: Order.find with paging sort order wrong
items.body:
With the latest version v7.0.1 following code gives wrong sort order on paging with since_id:

```
    API_VERSION = '2020-01'
    shop_url = f"https://{SHOP_NAME}.myshopify.com/admin/api/{API_VERSION}"
    shopify.ShopifyResource.set_site(shop_url)
    shopify.ShopifyResource.set_user(API_KEY)
    shopify.ShopifyResource.set_password(PASSWORD)


    orders = shopify.Order.find(limit=5)

    since_id = None
    for order in orders:
        since_id = order.id
        print(f'order id = {order.id}')
        
    print('load next batch')
    orders = shopify.Order.find(limit=5,since_id=since_id)

    for order in orders:
        since_id = order.id
        print(f'order id = {order.id}')
```

gives following output:

```
order id = 2048508199012
order id = 2048475660388
order id = 2048455606372
order id = 2048283050084
order id = 2048220168292
load next batch
order id = 2048283050084
order id = 2048455606372
order id = 2048475660388
order id = 2048508199012
```

As you can see, the second batch is sorted backwards only not including the last order from the first batch.

items.title: cursor-based pagination not working (header name case-sensitivity?)
items.body:
I am trying to implement the new cursor-based pagination, with ShopifyPythonAPI/6.0.1 on Python/2.7.16 and pyactiveresource 2.2.0. I am testing with the API version 2020-10.

`has_next_page()` always returns false for me even when there are more items. Looking at your source code, `PaginatedCollection`'s `__parse_pagination` method looks for `metadata['header']['Link']` yet for some reasons, all header names are in lower-cases on my environment.

```
>>> p = shopify.Product.find(limit=3)
>>> p.has_next_page()
False
>>> p.metadata['pagination']
{}
>>> p.metadata['headers']['link']
'<https://STORE.myshopify.com/admin/api/2020-01/products.json?limit=3&page_info=CURSOR>; rel="next"'
>>> p.metadata['headers']['Link']
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
KeyError: 'Link'
```

on a side note, it would be nice if we could retrieve page_info value from PaginatedCollection, so I can use it to fetch the next page. This way I don't need to keep the original page object to access the next page. I see `shopify.Product.find(page_info=CURSOR)` works, although i would feel better if it was documented. 

Thanks.

items.title: ShopifyResource.find does not propagate kwargs to PaginatedCollection
items.body:
Hey folks, I'm testing the new pagination and I've found that `resource.find(no_iter_next=True)`
doesn't work as expected (e.g. the resulting iterator will still fetch additional pages).

After having a quick look through the source code, it appears that this is because the `kwargs` are never passed through: https://github.com/Shopify/shopify_python_api/blob/master/shopify/base.py#L213

Overriding the variable on the collection works fine, but is non-ideal:
```python
        collection = resource.find(**kwargs)
        collection._no_iter_next = True
```

items.title: Problems while validating HMAC
items.body:
Hey all.
I'm trying to validate HMAC without success. The readme says "Ensure the provided hmac is valid. The hmac is signed by Shopify as explained below, in the Verification section.", but does not provide a "verification section". Edit: It seems this comes from the Help Center that gives an example in Ruby. On that example they say something like `secret = 'hush'`, but I did not understand where this comes from.

Here's my code so far, the main route is the redirect route after an user installs the app.

```
@main.route('/')
def index():
    api_secret = b'jfdklsjfkadskjlfads'

    # Get params
    code = request.args.get('code')    
    myhmac = request.args.get('hmac')
    shop = request.args.get('shop')
    state = request.args.get('state')
    timestamp = request.args.get('timestamp')
    
    # Generate "clean" parameters (without HMAC)
    clean = "code=" + code + "&" + "shop=" + shop + "&" + "state=" + state + "&" + "timestamp=" + timestamp
    clean = clean.encode('utf-8')
    myhmac = myhmac.encode('utf-8')

    # Compare HMAC
    # I'm guessing this is where things go wrong. I've tried with the api_secret (from the partners app API Keys), state, etc. But I don't know which "secret" should I put in here.
    digest = hmac.new(clean, api_secret, hashlib.sha256).digest()
    computed_hmac = base64.b64encode(digest)
    result = hmac.compare_digest(computed_hmac, myhmac)

    comparison_test = { "result": result }

    return jsonify(comparison_test)
```

Even though I don't get an error, it returns `false`. This is an app I created in Shopify Partners, with a developers store (with the developer view option enabled).

Any ideas on what I might be doing wrong?

items.title: API version 2019-10 fails with variant updates
items.body:
Hello,

I've found what I believe is a bug with the current version of the project (5.1.2).  Targeting API version 2019-10 with Shopify, a call to update the price of a product variant fails with a 400 Bad Request error.  The complete text of the error follows:

pyactiveresource.connection.BadRequest: Response(code=400, body="b'{"error":"Write requests to inventory_quantity and inventory_quantity_adjustment are no longer supported. Please use the Inventory Levels API."}

Steps to reproduce:

1. Create connection via private app key targeting API version 2019-10 (admin/api/2019-10)
2. Set shop resource
3. Set a new object as a product
4. From the product, set another new object as a product variant
5. Call <variant>.price = float(<price>)   (Running print(<variant>.price) does return the updated price here)
6. Call <variant>.save()

Upon calling save(), the above error is thrown.

After reviewing documentation, it appears that inventory_quantity should be removed from the list of variant attributes as it is fully deprecated in API version 2019-10.  This call works without issue targeting API version 2019-07.

items.title: how to list existing webhooks and delete them? / more Python API docs?
items.body:
Hi, I've just started with the Shopify API and I am pretty lost... sorry in advance that this question is so basic, but I can't really find instructions for basic-to-intermediate stuff (the kind of stuff that might come after the README for this GitHub repo) in the docs. So I could use a pointer on what to read.

For example I have created a few webhooks like the following and it works (I was basing this on somebody else's code that I found)

```
session = shopify.Session(shop, token)
shopify.ShopifyResource.activate_session(session)

new_webhook = shopify.Webhook()
new_webhook.address = mydomain + "/shopify/" + str(shop_id) + "/" + event
new_webhook.format = 'json'
new_webhook.topic = event
success = new_webhook.save()
```

But now I would like to list the existing webhooks and delete them, and I don't know where to look in the docs to find instructions for that. Also, if save() doesn't work, I'd like to see the error message for that but I can't figure out how.

More generally, I found the README on the main GitHub page (https://github.com/Shopify/shopify_python_api) to be helpful. What should I read after that to understand further how to use the Python API? When I go to the Shopify Docs page, I can find a lot of information on the REST API itself, but nothing on how to interact with it using the Python API.

In sum, where's the rest of the Python API documentation?

items.title: ITP 2.0 support
items.body:
Hey,

as [ITP-Impact](https://help.shopify.com/en/api/guides/itp-impact) states their is a workaround needed for embedded shopify apps in Safari 12.0+ dealing with webkits ITP 2.0 implementation.
Workarounds for ruby and nodejs are already implemented but not for python.
Is there a plan for implementing this in shopify_python_api as well?

Best regards
Dominik

items.title: Reading shop metafields: Discrepancy between AJAX call and backend view behavior
items.body:
I'm using the https://github.com/discolabs/django-shopify-auth/issues/45 with this, so I cross-posted there, but I'm asking here as well.

Getting the list of shop metaifleds works great if running on the server in a simple Django view:

```
def my_view(request):
    with request.user.session:
        shop = shopify.Shop().current()
        print(shop.metafields())    # returns [(metafield(1232543), metafields(143534534), etc]
```

However, if I do something like this (don't panic, I'm just experimenting) in an AJAX handler, it returns an empty array.

```
@csrf_exempt
def proxy_request(request):
    shop_user = AuthAppShopUser.objects.get(myshopify_domain=site)
    user = auth.authenticate(request=request, myshopify_domain=site, token=shop_user.token)
    if user:
        auth.login(request, user)
        
        with request.user.session:
            shop = shopify.Shop().current()
            print(shop.metafields())   # returns []
```

Thank you for any insight!

Shopify changes the URL from above, and changes the URL to:

                      ])
new_product.save()
##No errors are output, but doesn't create variants with options
if new_product.errors:
    print new_product.errors.full_messages()
print "Done"
Thanks in advanced,

Chris

items.title: Special Characters in query options are not accepted by Shopify's API
items.body:
If we try and find a specific order by name:
`order = shopify.Order.find(name='#1001')`

Through pyactiveresource.util.to_query (which is used to encode the query string for requests) this is converted to:
`GET https://storeurl.myshopify.com/admin/orders.json?name=%231001`
instead of
`GET https://storeurl.myshopify.com/admin/orders.json?name=#1001`

The former returns an empty list in the response. The latter returns the correct response with an order that it finds.

Seeing as though Shopify uses '#' by default in order names for new stores I would expect this to work without needing to patch pyactiveresource to not urlencode order names. 

Am I doing something wrong? How should I handle this?

items.title: CRITICAL: New "Invalid API key or access token" errors from unchanged code
items.body:
I create Shopify apps using this module along with a customized version of [django-shopify-auth](https://github.com/discolabs/django-shopify-auth). I have recently discovered that many of my apps (thankfully mostly development apps) which already have an installation work fine, but if I uninstall and re-install (yes, I'm handling session purges with the `app/uninstalled` webhook) I get authentication errors whenever I try to access any data via the API. Here's an example of the kind of exception I'm getting:

```
UnauthorizedAccess: Response(
    code = 401,
    body = "{"errors":"[API] Invalid API key or access token (unrecognized login or wrong password)"}",
    headers = {
        'x-request-id': '6b95887e-0f3d-417b-b8f4-fc0f6ed1ee03',
        'x-xss-protection': '1; mode=block; report=/xss-report?source%5Baction%5D=index&source%5Bapp%5D=Shopify&source%5Bcontroller%5D=admin%2Fproducts&source%5Bsection%5D=admin&source%5Buuid%5D=6b95887e-0f3d-417b-b8f4-fc0f6ed1ee03',
        'x-download-options': 'noopen',
        'x-content-type-options': 'nosniff',
        'content-security-policy': "default-src 'self' https://* shopify-pos://*; child-src 'self' https://* blob: data: shopify-pos://*; connect-src 'self' https://* wss://*; font-src 'self' https://* blob: data:; img-src 'self' https://* blob: data:; media-src 'self' https://* blob: data:; object-src 'self' https://* blob: data:; script-src https://cdn.shopify.com https://checkout.shopifycs.com https://js-agent.newrelic.com https://bam.nr-data.net https://dme0ih8comzn4.cloudfront.net https://api.stripe.com https://mpsnare.iesnare.com https://appcenter.intuit.com https://www.paypal.com https://stats.g.doubleclick.net https://www.google-analytics.com https://visitors.shopify.com https://v.shopify.com https://widget.intercom.io https://js.intercomcdn.com 'self' 'unsafe-inline' 'unsafe-eval'; style-src 'self' https://* 'unsafe-inline'; report-uri /csp-report?source%5Baction%5D=index&source%5Bapp%5D=Shopify&source%5Bcontroller%5D=admin%2Fproducts&source%5Bsection%5D=admin&source%5Buuid%5D=6b95887e-0f3d-417b-b8f4-fc0f6ed1ee03",
        'transfer-encoding': 'chunked',
        'x-dc': 'ash',
        'connection': 'close',
        'server': 'nginx',
        'x-shopid': '8973152',
        'x-permitted-cross-domain-policies': 'none',
        'date': 'Sat, 25 Feb 2017 18:22:38 GMT',
        'x-shardid': '5',
        'x-frame-options': 'DENY',
        'content-type': 'application/json; charset=utf-8',
        'www-authenticate': 'Basic Realm="Shopify API Authentication"'
    },
    msg="Unauthorized"
)
```

I've compared the raw request endpoints and header data, and they seem to be correct. As I said before, this is happening from multiple projects, unchanged from a point in time where this problem was not occurring. All signs indicate that there is some backend problem with Shopify, however I wanted to post this here anyway in case this package isn't up to speed on some authentication change that recently occurred, or (as it seems) is being rolled out.

If anyone has any info on this, please share- none of my live apps are currently affected, and I want to keep it that way.

P.S. It's not a scope permissions issue, as I'm testing with `shopify.Shop.current()`, which works with any scope permissions you have set up.

items.title: API Request ISO 8601 Datetime Fomat
items.body:
The Shopify API reference says:

> **updated_at_min**
> Show products last updated after date (**format: 2014-04-25T16:15:47-04:00**)

If I have a datetime object when making an API call, do I need to convert the datetime to a string of ISO 8601 format prior to making the request?

i.e. do I need to do this?

```
min_date = timezone.now()
shopify.Product.count(created_at_min = str(min_data.isoformat()))
```

My request would look like this then:

`https://[store-url].myshopify.com/admin/products/count.json?updated_at_min=2017-01-29T14%3A43%3A27-05%3A00`

Versus this (if I pass the unformatted datetime object in):

`https://[store-url].myshopify.com/admin/products/count.json?updated_at_min=2016-12-10+14%3A43%3A27-05%3A00`

(If so, why doesn't the Shopify Python API handle this conversion automatically, seems kind of silly?)

items.title: Helper method for uninstalling app
items.body:
Howdy!

Love this library. Really make integrating with Shopify easy as pie. [Shopify docs](https://help.shopify.com/api/guides/authentication/uninstalling-applications) indicate that it's possible to programmatically uninstall an app by issuing a `DELETE` to `https://someshop.myshopify.com/admin/api_permissions/current.json` (authenticated of course). I know I can do this on my own without any helpers, per se, but it'd be nice to see a helper method somewhere.

I'd be glad to spit out an implementation, but I wanted some guidance and opinions: would it be necessary to define a new resource, or would it be reasonable -- if not a little hacky -- to bolt it onto `shopify.Session` or something?

Let me know what y'all think.

items.title: Getting TypeError when trying to Webhook.find()
items.body:
Just updated to latest everything:
py3.5
ShopifyAPI (2.1.5)
pyactiveresource (2.1.2)

And the following code:

```
    if not shopify.Webhook.find(topic='orders/paid'):
```

Raise the following exception:

```
  File ".../venv/lib/python3.5/site-packages/pyactiveresource/activeresource.py", line 720, in _prefix_parameters
    for match in template.pattern.finditer(path):
TypeError: cannot use a string pattern on a bytes-like object
```

Some basic print debug shows the value of `path` at that point is b''.

If I modify the offending code to use `path.encode('utf-8')` it succeeds, but fails later at:

```
  File ".../venv/lib/python3.5/site-packages/pyactiveresource/activeresource.py", line 737, in _prefix
    path = re.sub('/$', '', cls.prefix_source)
  File ".../venv/lib/python3.5/re.py", line 182, in sub
    return _compile(pattern, flags).sub(repl, string, count)
TypeError: cannot use a string pattern on a bytes-like object
```

So either this is byte/string failure in pyactiveresource, or ShopifyAPI isn't setting values on its Webhook resource that the other lib needs.

items.title: Attaching Images - Decode required for Python 3 compatibility

```
with open("some_image.jpg","rb") as f:

```

img will be bytes while the attachment needs to be a string to the JSONified. So in image.py:

```
def attach_image(self, data, filename=None):
    self.attributes["attachment"] = base64.b64encode(data).decode() #decode() for Python 3
    if filename:
        self.attributes["filename"] = filename
```

I am not sure how to keep it Python 2 compatible.

items.title: Need new publish/unpublish methods (and docs) to match API changes
items.body:
I was recently bitten by a change to the Shopify API; you no longer hide a published object by changing the "published_at" attribute to None. This affects Product, SmartCollection, CustomCollection, Page, Article, maybe more. The new way to hide an object is by setting its "published" attribute to False.

I haven't seen any Shopify announcement, nor any changes to the Ruby API gem. I only found out about it from the follow-up after I called tech support. Looks like the online docs were updated at some point:

https://help.shopify.com/api/reference/smartcollection#update
